ygData.subject: Open Question Re: Significance of Composition of Generation Zero

Andy, note I only said that there is no "obvious advantage."  That is 
not =
a dismissal, that's just saying that it's not clear whether it 
would buy a=
n advantage or not.  It very well may do so.   If you have 
posted evidence=
 of such an advantage, it's possible I missed it in 
the past.  If not, I'd=
 be happy to take a look.

I understand that you are concerned with coverag=
e and in particular 
visiting the same point in the search space more than =
once.  I 
remember that you showed that there is some percentage of such re=
-
visitation in the search space in NEAT (as happens in fact in many 
evolu=
tionry and learning algorithms).   It appears that if you manage 
to avoid =
some revisitation (without paying a different cost for 
avoiding it), you c=
ould maybe at best double the efficiency or the 
algorithm, or something in=
 that ballpark.  However, I am not sure 
that the cost of revisitation is r=
eally any worse than the cost of 
trying to prevent it?  It depends on how =
clever the preventation 
scheme is.

You also mention that NEAT's standard =
parameters are "conservative."  
Can you give an example of what you would =
consider more "liberal" 
parameters?   Are you talking about e.g. higher mu=
tation rates?

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "afcarl2" <a.carl@...> wro=
te:
>
> Ken,
> 
> With all due respect,
> 
> 
> > The idea that you might c=
reate many initial populations and 
> evaluate 
> > all of them is not buyi=
ng any obvious advantage because you still 
> end 
> > up having to evaluat=
e all those initial populations.
> 
> I disagree. For standard NEAT params,=
 test cases (the results 
summary 
> of which has been included in prior po=
stings) demonstrate that the 
> product of number of individuals times gene=
rations are not created 
> equal. 
> 
> 
> > Note that search efficiency is=
 generally considered to be number 
of 
> > evaluations, so if 1,000 evalua=
tions are added at the get-go, 
some 
> > consequence would need to make up=
 for that initial investment.
> 
> 
> Specifically, for a given number of e=
vaulations (i.e. # individuals 
* 
> generations), higher fitness was achie=
ved when the composition 
> included more "0 generation" evaluations rather=
 than less.
> 
> 
> > The answer is not obvious because the dynamics of bot=
h strategies 
> are 
> > quite complex and domain-dependent.
> 
> 
> Reason=
ably so, but not an adequate justification to set-aside the 
> issue. Until=
 you actually implement code infrastructure to attempt 
to 
> quantify such=
 things as: a) exact genome duplication as measured by 
> visitation of des=
ign points, not just genome structure, b) 
effective 
> genome duplication =
(i.e. so close to be effectivily a duplicate), 
and 
> c) coverage of the d=
esign space, you will not uncover just how 
> redundant and limited coverag=
e of the design space is for standard 
> NEAT params for a given population=
 size and number of generations.
> 
> I am a huge fan of the NEAT method. B=
ut the method will not achieve 
> its potential to handle practical real-wo=
rld problems until these 
> profound inefficiencies are addressed.
> 
> The=
 standard NEAT params appear to be very conservative, resting on 
> the ben=
efits of the NEAT method itself to make up for the undue 
> burden of their=
 conservatisim. But that only goes as far as the 
> trivialness of the fitn=
ess function evaluation. After which it 
sinks 
> under the computational w=
eight of its own inefficiency and 
> conservatisism for practical problems =
where the fitness evaluation 
is 
> non-trival. It would be very disappoint=
ing that the benefits of the 
> NEAT method get lost due to the failure to =
address the significance 
> and adaptive control potential characteristics =
of the NEAT params.
> 
> Dancing rag-dolls reveal applicability of the NEAT=
 method to new 
and 
> interesting areas, but there is more fundamental res=
earch required 
on 
> the exploitation of the NEAT params before you will s=
ee the NEAT 
> method commonly applied to practical real-world problems, as=
 it 
> rightfully should/could be.
> 
> Hand waving over "complex and domai=
n-dependent" is an inadequate 
> justification for chosing to ignore the is=
sue, and instead focus on 
> new and interesting areas in which the issue i=
s not addressed.
> 
> Andy Carl
> 
>

th Stanley" <kstanley@> wrote:
> >
> > The distribution of the initial gene=
rations indeed can affect the 
> > course of evolution.  However, it is dif=
ficult to make informed a 
> > priori decisions about the initial populatio=
n before an 
experiment 
> is 
> > run, because little may be known about t=
he structure of the 
search 
> > space.  However, I believe there has been =
work on the composition 
> of 
> > initial populations in GAs and the right=
 random distribution 
(e.g. 
> > uniform vs. normal, or something else) of =
individuals in that 
> > population to best cover the search space.  
> > 
=
> > The idea that you might create many initial populations and 
> evaluate=
 
> > all of them is not buying any obvious advantage because you still 
> =
end 
> > up having to evaluate all those initial populations.  For 
example=
, 
> > let's say that the population size is 100.  Then if you generate 
10=
 
> > initial populations, you end up evaluating 1,000 individuals 
before =

> > deciding in which population to invest further.  On the other 
hand, 
=
> > if you start with simply one population, then after 1,000 
> evaluatins=
 
> > you will have proceeded 10 generations.  So the question is, 
which 
=
> > was more effective, evaluating 10 random populations, or 
evaluating 
>=
 > 10 generations of evolutionary search?  
> > 
> > The answer is not obvi=
ous because the dynamics of both strategies 
> are 
> > quite complex and d=
omain-dependent.  One could argue for the 
> > advantages of either.  Howev=
er, what can be said is that there is 
> no 
> > knock-down reason that hav=
ing multiple initial populations will 
> > improve efficiency.  
> > 
> > N=
ote that search efficiency is generally considered to be number 
of 
> > ev=
aluations, so if 1,000 evaluations are added at the get-go, 
some 
> > cons=
equence would need to make up for that initial investment. 
> > 
> > ken

Is there any significance to the composition of generation zero

ards to 
a

> > > fitness potential via complexification?

o,
